com.cleo.lexicom.beans

Class LexURIFile

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.cleo.lexicom.beans.LexURIFile

  • public abstract class LexURIFile
extends java.lang.Object
    LexURIFile is a class to be extended to create a SchemeFile class in order to support a URI representation for user-defined files and/or directory objects where the underlying system may be a file system, database, queue, or pipe. All schemes must start with a letter followed by one or more alpha-numeric characters followed by a colon.

    Some example URIs are:

    • jms:jndi:jms/InboxQueue?jndiConnectionFactoryName=jms/ConnFact&filenameProp=filename
    • msmq:DIRECT=OS:.\private$\Inbox?createQueue=true
    • VLPipe:FTPPipeDevTest\myMailbox
    • MyFS:\Inbox
    • hdfs:\hdfsnamenode:50070\Inbox

    Since a SchemeFile represents a file or directory, this abstract class is based on the methods in the java.io.File class with some additional methods.

    • LexURIFile.getURIException()
    • LexURIFile.getLexWildcardInfo()
    • LexURIFile.getType()

    The implementing class must extend the LexURIFile class and implement all abstract classes.

    VersaLex URI File System Interface Description

    VLTrader and Harmony have has a method for accessing files using java code outside of the typical VersaLex jars. These custom-written classes are accessed based on the scheme at the start of the URI found in a host Inbox / Outbox or the source / destination specified in an action. A file system type URI may also be used for local user folders.

    The Java classes that are called are configured in system properties. These properties are typically configured with -D parameters. These system properties can also be configured in the system.properties file found in the conf/ folder under VersaLex. When VersaLex detects a URI, it will check if associated classes have been configured for that scheme.

    Four system properties are used to configure a single scheme. The property name is all lowercase including the scheme name. The property values are mixed case.

    System Property Required Description
    cleo.uri.scheme.file Yes This property defines the custom class to be used as the File object. This custom class must extend cleo.lexicom.beans.LexURIFile. LexURIFile is an abstract class that extends java.io.File. The suggested class name for this class is com.companyabc.scheme.SchemeFile.

    The schemeFile class must implement two constructors:

    • SchemeFile(String uri)
    • SchemeFile(String parentUri, String child)
    These constructors should first call their respective super(...) methods.
    cleo.uri.scheme.inputstream Yes This property defines the custom class to be used for the InputStream object. This custom class must extend java.io.InputStream.

    The SchemeInputStream class must implement one constructor:

    • SchemeInputStream(LexURIFile lexURIFile)
      NOTE: lexURIFile can be cast to a SchemeFile so that information regarding the SchemeFile can be retrieved.

    The SchemeInputStream class must override all the java.io.InputStream methods:

    • available()
    • close()
    • mark(int readlimit)
    • markSupported()
    • read()
    • read(byte[] b)
    • read(byte[] b, int off, int len)
    • reset()
    • skip(long n)

    The suggested class name for this class is com.companyabc.scheme.SchemeInputStream.

    cleo.uri.scheme.outputstream Yes This property defines the custom class to be used for the OutputStream object. This custom class must extend java.io.OutputStream.

    The SchemeOutputStream class must implement one constructor:

    • SchemeOutputStream(LexURIFile lexURIFile, boolean append)
      NOTE: lexURIFile can be cast to a SchemeFile so that information regarding the SchemeFile can be retrieved.

    The SchemeOutputStream class must override all the java.io.OutputStream methods:

    • close()
    • flush()
    • write(byte[] b)
    • write(byte[] b, int off, int len)
    • write(int b)

    The suggested class name for this class is com.companyabc.scheme.SchemeOutputStream.

    cleo.uri.scheme.classpath No This property defines the Java class path to the jars containing this scheme implementation. It can also contain any other jars needed for this scheme. The jar file(s) can be in any location accessible by the VersaLex application. If you wish to locate the jars within the VersaLex software installation folder, the suggested location is the lib\uri\ folder under the VersaLex installation folder. A separate class loader is used for each scheme. If certain jar files need to be loaded by the base class loader (such as GlassFish jar files for the JMS scheme), then these jars should be specified using the system property cleo.additional.classpath (see below).

    Example: For the hdfs scheme, the system properties could be defined using the following command line parameters

    • -Dcleo.uri.hdfs.file=com.companyabc.hdfs.HdfsFile
    • -Dcleo.uri.hdfs.inputstream=com.companyabc.hdfs.HdfsInputStream
    • -Dcleo.uri.hdfs.outputstream=com.companyabc.hdfs.HdfsOutputStream
    • -Dcleo.uri.hdfs.classpath=C:/MyURIs/hdfsuri.jar;D:/Hadoop/hadoop-core.jar

    An additional system property can be used to configure other jar files that need to be included the base class path.

    System Property Required Description
    cleo.additional.classpath No This property defines a list of additional JAR files that need to be included the base class path. These classes will be appended to the end of the VersaLex class path. The JAR file paths are separated by the path separator character. On UNIX systems, this character is ':' and on Microsoft Windows systems it is ';'.

    Example: For a JMS scheme using GlassFish, the system property could be defined using the following command line parameter

    • -Dcleo.additional.classpath=C:/glassfish3/glassfish/lib/gf-client.jar

    • Constructor Detail

      • LexURIFile

        public LexURIFile(java.lang.String uri)
        Creates a LexURIFile object using the provided URI.

        The uri in this case could represent a directory or a file. This constructor should not be called directly but should be called through the super() function of the class extending LexURIFile.

        Parameters:
        uri - String containing the URI representing the directory or file.

      • LexURIFile

        public LexURIFile(java.lang.String parentURI,
                  java.lang.String child)
        Creates a LexURIFile object using the provided parent URI and child.

        The parentURI in this case represents a directory. The child represents the file within the parent directory. This constructor should not be called directly but should be called through the super() function of the class extending LexURIFile.

        Parameters:
        parentURI - String containing the URI representing a directory.
        child - String containing the filename portion of the URI. This should only be the name and not include the parameter name.

    • Method Detail

      • canRead

        public abstract boolean canRead()
        Tests whether the application can read the directory or file represented by this SchemeFile.

        For a queue/pipe/database, this could always return true and let any failures occur through the SchemeInputStream.

        Returns:
        true if the directory or file represented by this SchemeFile exists and can be read by the application; false otherwise

      • canWrite

        public abstract boolean canWrite()
        Tests whether the application can modify the directory or file represented by this SchemeFile.

        For a queue/pipe/database, this could always return true and let any failures occur through the SchemeOutputStream.

        Returns:
        true if the scheme system actually contains this directory or file and the application is allowed to write to the directory or file; false otherwise.

      • compareTo

        public abstract int compareTo(LexURIFile pathname)
        Compares the URIs of two LexURIFiles lexicographically.
        Parameters:
        pathname - The SchemeFile to be compared to this SchemeFile
        Returns:
        Zero if the argument is equal to this SchemeFile, a value less than zero if this SchemeFile's URI is lexicographically less than the argument, or a value greater than zero if this SchemeFile's URI is lexicographically greater than the argument.

      • createNewFile

        public abstract boolean createNewFile()
                               throws java.io.IOException
        Creates a new, empty file named by this SchemeFile if and only if a file with this name does not yet exist. The check for the existence of the file and the creation of the file if it does not exist are a single operation that is atomic with respect to all other scheme activities that might affect the file.

        For queues, pipes, and databases, this method may do nothing besides return the boolean value.

        Returns:
        true if the named file does not exist and was successfully created; false if the named file already exists
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If an I/O error occurred

      • delete

        public abstract boolean delete()
        Deletes the file. If this SchemeFile represents directory, then the directory must be empty in order to be deleted.
        Returns:
        true if the file or directory is successfully deleted; false otherwise

      • equals

        public abstract boolean equals(java.lang.Object obj)
        Tests this SchemeFile for equality with the given object. Returns true if the argument is not null and is a SchemeFile that denotes the same directory or file as this SchemeFile.
        Overrides:
        equals in class java.lang.Object
        Parameters:
        obj - object to be compared with this SchemeFile
        Returns:
        true if the objects are the same; false otherwise

      • exists

        public abstract boolean exists()
        Tests whether the directory or file exists.

        For queues/pipes/databases: If a specific filename is included in the SchemeFile's URI, then this checks for that specific item in the queue/pipe/database exists. If the SchemeFile represents a directory, then this returns true if the queue/pipe/database table exists.

        Returns:
        true if the file or directory exists; false otherwise

      • getAbsoluteFile

        public abstract LexURIFile getAbsoluteFile()
        Returns the absolute form of this SchemeFile. Equivalent to new SchemeFile(this.LexURIFile.getAbsolutePath()).

        Since SchemeFile extends LexURIFile, a SchemeFile can and should be returned.

        Returns:
        The SchemeFile denoting the same directory or file as this SchemeFile

      • getAbsolutePath

        public abstract java.lang.String getAbsolutePath()
        Returns the SchemeFile's absolute URI string of this SchemeFile.

        Since the URI is already absolute, then the pathname string is simply returned as if by the LexURIFile.getPath() method.

        Returns:
        The SchemeFile's absolute pathname URI string denoting the same directory or file as this URI

      • getUnderlyingPath

        public java.lang.String getUnderlyingPath()
        Returns the absolute path of the underlying file (if possible) of this SchemeFile. This will return the URI path unless overridden by the URI implementation.
        Returns:
        The path of the underlying path (if possible) of the SchemeFile object.

      • getCanonicalFile

        public abstract LexURIFile getCanonicalFile()
        Returns the canonical form of this SchemeFile. Equivalent to new SchemeFile(this.LexURIFile.getCanonicalPath()).

        Since SchemeFile extends LexURIFile, a SchemeFile can and should be returned.

        Returns:
        A SchemeFile object with the same URI.

      • getCanonicalPath

        public abstract java.lang.String getCanonicalPath()
                                           throws java.io.IOException
        Returns the canonical pathname string of this SchemeFile.

        Since the SchemeFile is already absolute, then the pathname string is simply returned as if by the LexURIFile.getPath() method.

        Returns:
        Returns the canonical pathname string of this SchemeFile.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If an I/O error occurred

      • getName

        public abstract java.lang.String getName()
        Returns the name of the file.

        For a file system, this would be the last portion of the filename path. For a queue/pipe/database, this is filename portion of the URI not including the parameter name.

        Examples:

        • msmq:DIRECT=OS:.\private$\Outbox?msgLabel=test.edi
          getName() would return test.edi

        • msmq:DIRECT=OS:.\private$\Outbox?msgLabel=*.edi
          getName() would return *.edi

        • jms:jndi:jms/InboxQueue?msgFilename=[test.edi]&jndiConnectionFactoryName=jms/ConnectionFactory&filenameProp=filename
          getName() would return [test.edi]
        Returns:
        Returns the name of the file represented by this SchemeFile.

      • getParent

        public abstract java.lang.String getParent()
        Returns the parent of the directory or file.

        For a file system, this would be all but the last portion of the filename path.

        For a queue/pipe/database:

        • If the SchemeFile represents a file, then the URI without any file specific parameters is returned.
        • If the SchemeFile represents a folder, then a null is returned.

          Examples:

          • msmq:DIRECT=OS:.\private$\Outbox?msgLabel=test.edi
            getParent() would return msmq:DIRECT=OS:.\private$\Outbox

          • msmq:DIRECT=OS:.\private$\Outbox
            getParent() would return null

          • jms:jndi:jms/InboxQueue?msgFilename=[test.edi]&jndiConnectionFactoryName=jms/ConnectionFactory&filenameProp=filename
            getParent() would return jms:jndi:jms/InboxQueue?jndiConnectionFactoryName=jms/ConnectionFactory&filenameProp=filename
        Returns:
        Returns the name of the parent represented by this SchemeFile.

      • getParentFile

        public abstract LexURIFile getParentFile()
        Returns the SchemeFile object of this SchemeFile's parent, or null if this pathname does not name a parent directory.

        Since SchemeFile extends LexURIFile, a SchemeFile can and should be returned.

        If this SchemeFile has a parent, then this is equivalent to new SchemeFile(this.LexURIFile.getParent()).

        Returns:
        The SchemeFile object of the parent directory named by this SchemeFile, or null if this SchemeFile does not name a parent

        public abstract java.lang.String getPath()
        Converts this SchemeFile object into a URI string.
        Returns:
        Returns the URI string for the SchemeFile object

      • getPathWithoutParameters

        public java.lang.String getPathWithoutParameters()
        Returns URI with parameters removed. Override this method if the using the last ? is not sufficient.
        Returns:
        Returns the URI string for the SchemeFile object without any parameters

      • getParameters

        public java.lang.String getParameters()
        Returns parameters of the URI. Override this method if the using the last ? is not sufficient.
        Returns:
        Returns the parameter portion of the URI string for the SchemeFile object

      • paramsIndex

        public static int paramsIndex(java.lang.String uriString)
        Finds the index of the ? marking the start of the parameters
        Parameters:
        uriString - String containing the URI NOTE: If wildcards are used within the path, then either URI parameters must be specified or ? must be added at the end of the path. In other words, the right-most ? must signal the start of the parameters (even if there aren't any parameters).
        Returns:
        Returns the index of the "?" deemed to be the start of the parameters

      • isAbsolute

        public abstract boolean isAbsolute()
        Returns true since all URI strings will be absolute.
        Returns:
        true

      • isDirectory

        public abstract boolean isDirectory()
        Tests whether this SchemeFile represents a directory.

        For file systems, returns true if this SchemeFile item exists and is a directory.

        For queues/pipes/databases, returns false if the SchemeFile is meant to represent a message/item/record in the queue/pipe/database. It returns true if the SchemeFile is meant to represent the queue/pipe/database table itself.

        Returns:
        true if the SchemeFile represents a directory; false otherwise

      • isFile

        public abstract boolean isFile()
        Tests whether this SchemeFile represents a file.

        For file systems, returns true if this SchemeFile item exists and is a file.

        For queues/pipes/databases, returns true if the SchemeFile is meant to represent a message/item/record in the queue/pipe/database. It returns false if the SchemeFile is meant to represent the queue/pipe/database table itself.

        Returns:
        true if the SchemeFile represents a directory; false otherwise

      • isHidden

        public abstract boolean isHidden()
        Tests whether the file named by this SchemeFile is a hidden file.

        For file systems, the definition of hidden is operating system dependant.

        For queues/pipes/databases, this would normally always return false

        Returns:
        true if the item is hidden; false otherwise

      • lastModified

        public abstract long lastModified()
        Returns the time that the SchemeFile was last modified.

        For file systems, this would be the last modified timestamp on the file.

        For queues/pipes/databases, this could be the time when the message/item/record was added to the queue/pipe/database.

        Returns:
        A long value representing the time the SchemeFile was last modified, measured in milliseconds since the epoch (00:00:00 GMT, January 1, 1970), or 0L if the file does not exist or if an I/O error occurs

      • length

        public abstract long length()
        Returns the length of the file represented by this SchemeFile.

        For queues/pipes/databases, this would be the length, in bytes, of the message/item/database field. For file systems, this would be the length, in bytes, of the file.

        Returns:
        The length, in bytes, of the file represented by this SchemeFile, or 0L if the file does not exist.

      • list

        public abstract java.lang.String[] list()
        Returns an array of strings naming the files and directories in the directory represented by this SchemeFile.

        If this SchemeFile does not represent a directory, then this method returns null. Otherwise an array of strings is returned, one for each file or directory in the directory.

        For file systems, names denoting the directory itself and the directory's parent directory are not included in the result. Each string is a file name rather than a complete path.

        For queues/pipes/databases, each string is a complete path including the file name. The URI should also include any additional information uniquely identifying the item such as a message ID or database primary key. This is because the filename is not necessarily unique in these systems.

        For example:
        If the list() was called for a URI of msmq:DIRECT=OS:.\private$\Outbox
        The following is an example of return values:

        • msmq:DIRECT=OS:.\private$\Outbox?msgLabel=test.edi&msgID=aced99d8-1e38-41c1-855f-26d13e977e7e\7893370&length=1533&arrival=20120315-160240
        • msmq:DIRECT=OS:.\private$\Outbox?msgLabel=abc.edi&msgID=aced99d8-1e38-41c1-855f-26d13e977e7e\7893376&length=1533&arrival=20120315-160240
        • msmq:DIRECT=OS:.\private$\Outbox?msgLabel=test100K.edi&msgID=aced99d8-1e38-41c1-855f-26d13e977e7e\7893361&length=102400&arrival=20120315-160240
        • msmq:DIRECT=OS:.\private$\Outbox?msgLabel=test100K.edi&msgID=aced99d8-1e38-41c1-855f-26d13e977e7e\7893364&length=102400&arrival=20120315-160240

        There is no guarantee that the name strings in the resulting array will appear in any specific order; they are not, in particular, guaranteed to appear in alphabetical order.

        Returns:
        An array of strings naming the files and directories in the directory denoted by this SchemeFile. The array will be empty if the directory is empty. Returns null if this SchemeFile does not represent a directory, or if an I/O error occurs.

      • listFiles

        public abstract LexURIFile[] listFiles()
        Returns an array of SchemeFile objects in the directory denoted by this SchemeFile.

        If this SchemeFile does not denote a directory, then this method returns null. Otherwise an array of SchemeFile objects is returned, one for each file or directory in the directory. Pathnames denoting the directory itself and the directory's parent directory are not included in the result.

        There is no guarantee that the name strings in the resulting array will appear in any specific order; they are not, in particular, guaranteed to appear in alphabetical order.

        Since SchemeFile extends LexURIFile, an array of SchemeFile can and should be returned.

        Returns:
        An array of SchemeFiles denoting the files and directories in the directory denoted by this SchemeFile. The array will be empty if the directory is empty. Returns null if this SchemeFile does not denote a directory, or if an I/O error occurs.

      • listFiles

        public abstract LexURIFile[] listFiles(LexURIFileFilter filter)
        Returns an array of SchemeFile objects filtered by the LexURIFileFilter.

        Since SchemeFile extends LexURIFile, an array of SchemeFile can and should be returned.

        The SchemeFile code should perform something similar to the following to determine if the LexURIFile (SchemeFile) is acceptable to be returned in the array.

        The following example is for an Hdfs scheme. 

         
  public HdfsFile[] listFiles(LexURIFileFilter filter) {
    // Throw SecurityException if URI was bad in constructor
    if (this.uriSyntaxException != null) 
      throw new SecurityException(this.uriSyntaxException);

    // Build list of all items
    String[] uriFileList = this.list();
    if (uriFileList == null)
      return null;

    // Build list of acceptable items
    ArrayList<HdfsFile> fileList = new ArrayList<HdfsFile>();
    for (int ii = 0; ii < uriFileList.length; ii++) {
      HdfsFile hdfsFile = new HdfsFile(uriFileList[ii]);
      if ((filter == null) || (filter.accept(hdfsFile)))
        fileList.add(hdfsFile);
    }

    // Return array of accepted items
    return fileList.toArray(new HdfsFile[fileList.size()]);
  }
        Parameters:
        filter - A LexURIFileFilter implemented with VersaLex. The SchemeFile implementation should call filter.accept(lexURIFile) method to determine if this SchemeFile should be included in the return array.
        Returns:
        Returns an array of SchemeFile objects filtered by filter.

      • mkdir

        public abstract boolean mkdir()
        Creates the directory named by this SchemeFile.

        For SchemeFile types that do not support subdirectories, such as queues/pipes/databases, this should return true.

        Returns:
        true if the directory was created; false otherwise

      • mkdirs

        public abstract boolean mkdirs()
        Creates the directory named by this abstract pathname, including any necessary but nonexistent parent directories. Note that if this operation fails it may have succeeded in creating some of the necessary parent directories.

        For SchemeFile types that do not support subdirectories, such as queues/pipes/databases, this should return true.

        Returns:
        true if the directory was created, along with all necessary parent directories; false otherwise

      • renameTo

        public abstract boolean renameTo(LexURIFile dest)
        Renames the SchemeFile

        If renaming is not supported, true should be returned.

        Parameters:
        dest - The new name (contained within the SchemeFile) for the named file
        Returns:
        true if the renaming succeeded or is not supported; false otherwise

      • setLastModified

        public abstract boolean setLastModified(long time)
        Sets the last-modified time of the file or directory named by this SchemeFile.

        If setting the last modified time is not supported, then either true can be returned or a SecurityException may be thrown.

        Parameters:
        time - The new last-modified time, measured in milliseconds since the epoch (00:00:00 GMT, January 1, 1970)
        Returns:
        true if the operation succeeded; false otherwise

      • setReadable

        public abstract boolean setReadable(boolean readable)
        A method to set the owner's read permission for this SchemeFile.

        If this is not supported for the scheme, then either true can be returned or a SecurityException may be thrown.

        Parameters:
        readable - If true, sets the access permission to allow read operations; if false to disallow read operations
        Returns:
        true if the operation succeeded or is not supported

      • setReadable

        public abstract boolean setReadable(boolean readable,
                                    boolean ownerOnly)
        Sets the owner's or everybody's read permission for this SchemeFile.

        If this is not supported for the scheme, then either true can be returned or a SecurityException may be thrown.

        Parameters:
        readable - If true, sets the access permission to allow read operations; if false to disallow read operations
        ownerOnly - If true, the read permission applies only to the owner's read permission; otherwise, it applies to everybody. If the underlying file system can not distinguish the owner's read permission from that of others, then the permission will apply to everybody, regardless of this value.
        Returns:
        true if the operation succeeded or is not supported

      • setReadOnly

        public abstract boolean setReadOnly()
        Marks the file or directory named by this SchemeFile so that only read operations are allowed.

        If this is not supported for the scheme, then either true can be returned or a SecurityException may be thrown.

        Returns:
        true if the operation succeeded or is not supported; false otherwise

      • setWritable

        public boolean setWritable(boolean writable)
        A method to set the owner's write permission for this SchemeFile.

        If this is not supported for the scheme, then either true can be returned or a SecurityException may be thrown. *

        NOTE: The default implementation of this method ALWAYS throws an exception.

        Parameters:
        writable - If true, sets the access permission to allow write operations; if false to disallow write operations
        Returns:
        true if the operation succeeded or is not supported

      • toString

        public abstract java.lang.String toString()
        Returns the URI string of this SchemeFile. This is the same string returned by the LexURIFile.getPath() method.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        The string form of this SchemeFile

      • list

        public java.lang.String[] list(java.io.FilenameFilter filter)
        Returns an array of strings naming the files and directories in the directory represented by this SchemeFile that satisfy the specified filter. The behavior of this method is the same as that of the LexURIFile.list() method, except that the strings in the returned array must satisfy the filter. If the given filter is null then all names are accepted. Otherwise, a name satisfies the filter if and only if the value true results when the FilenameFilter.accept() method of the filter is invoked on this abstract pathname and the name of a file or directory in the directory that it denotes.

        NOTES:

        • The default implementation of this method ALWAYS throws an exception.
        • This method should be overridden when this scheme is being used for local user folders.
        Parameters:
        filter - A filename filter
        Returns:
        An array of strings naming the files and directories in the directory denoted by this this SchemeFile that were accepted by the given filter. The array will be empty if the directory is empty or if no names were accepted by the filter. Returns null if this abstract pathname does not denote a directory, or if an I/O error occurs.

      • listFiles

        public LexURIFile[] listFiles(java.io.FilenameFilter filter)
        Returns an array of abstract pathnames denoting the files and directories in the directory denoted by this this SchemeFile that satisfy the specified filter. The behavior of this method is the same as that of the LexURIFile.listFiles() method, except that the pathnames in the returned array must satisfy the filter. If the given filter is null then all pathnames are accepted. Otherwise, a pathname satisfies the filter if and only if the value true results when the FilenameFilter.accept() method of the filter is invoked on this abstract pathname and the name of a file or directory in the directory that it denotes.

        NOTE: The default implementation of this method ALWAYS throws an exception.

        Parameters:
        filter - A filename filter
        Returns:
        An array of abstract pathnames denoting the files and directories in the directory denoted by this abstract pathname. The array will be empty if the directory is empty. Returns null if this abstract pathname does not denote a directory, or if an I/O error occurs.

      • hashCode

        public int hashCode()
        Computes a hash code for this URI.

        This is implemented in LexURIFile and can be overridden if needed.

        Overrides:
        hashCode in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        A hash code for this URI

      • getType

        public abstract LexFileType getType()
        Returns the LexFileType for this SchemeFile.

        This should return one of the following depending on the type of the implemented scheme:

        • LexFileType.DATABASE
        • LexFileType.FILESYSTEM
        • LexFileType.PIPE
        • LexFileType.QUEUE

        Although databases are described in the javadocs as not having subdirectories, it would be possible to have a directory-like structure by storing the directory path in the database. If your intent is to support subdirectories using a database, then the LexFileType returned should be LexFileType.FILESYSTEM and the URI should be something that resembles a file system. Such as:
        myDB:\SomeDir\SubDir1\SubDir2\filename

        Returns:
        Returns the appropriate LexFileType for this SchemeFile.

      • getURIException

        public abstract java.lang.Exception getURIException()
        Returns an exception generated during the SchemeFile constructor.

        If there is a problem with the URI, an exception should not be thrown during the constructor. Instead the exception should be saved and getURIException() should return this exception. In addition, if any method is called after a constructor with a bad URI, the saved exception should be thrown at the time the method is called.

        Returns:
        The exception generated during the SchemeFile constructor. Otherwise a null should be returned.

      • getLexWildcardInfo

        public abstract LexWildcardInfo getLexWildcardInfo()
        Returns an object representing the wildcard information in the URI.

        This should interrogate the URI and return a LexWildcardInfo object created with LexWildcardInfo(String path, String wildcard). If there is no wildcard ('*', '?', or '[regex]') in the filename portion of the URI, then a null object should be returned. If a wildcard exists in the filename portion of the URI, the path should be a valid URI without the filename parameter. The wildcard would be the value portion of the filename parameter.

        Examples:

        • msmq:DIRECT=OS:.\private$\Outbox?msgLabel=test.edi
          This would return a null object as there is no wildcard.

        • msmq:DIRECT=OS:.\private$\Outbox?msgLabel=*.edi
          This would return a new LexWildcardInfo( "msmq:DIRECT=OS:.\private$\Outbox", "*.edi" ) object.

        • jms:jndi:jms/InboxQueue?msgFilename=[test.edi]&jndiConnectionFactoryName=jms/ConnectionFactory&filenameProp=filename
          This would return a new LexWildcardInfo( "jms:jndi:jms/InboxQueue?jndiConnectionFactoryName=jms/ConnectionFactory&filenameProp=filename", "[test.edi]" ) object.
        Returns:
        Returns a LexWildcardInfo object if a wildcard is present or null otherwise.

      • canBeLocalUserRoot

        public boolean canBeLocalUserRoot()
        Returns whether or not this scheme can be used as a Local User Root. This can be overridden if necessary in the URI.
        Returns:
        Returns whether or not this scheme can be used as a Local User Root.

      • sanitizeFilename

        public static java.lang.String sanitizeFilename(java.lang.String name)
        Sanitizes the name string so it can be used as a filename.

        This function returns a string with the following characters replaced with an underscore ( _ ):

        : \ / * ? | < > "

        Parameters:
        name - String to sanitize to become a valid filename.
        Returns:
        Returns a sanitized string than can be used as a filename.

      • debug

        public static void debug(java.lang.String message)
        Writes a message to the VersaLex debug file.

        Writes to the VersaLex debug file if the Debug Option, URI, is enabled and the System Debug Level is Debug or higher.

        Parameters:
        message - Message to write to the debug file.

      • debug

        public static void debug(boolean always,
                         java.lang.String message)
        Writes a message to the VersaLex debug file.

        If always is true, then it writes to the VersaLex debug file even if the Debug Option, URI, is not enabled. However, the System Debug Level must be Debug or higher in order for the message to be logged.

        Parameters:
        always - Set to true if you want to write to the debug file regardless of the state of the URI Debug Option.
        message - Message to write to the debug file.

      • debug

        public static void debug(java.lang.String message,
                         java.lang.Throwable ex)
        Writes a message and exception to the VersaLex debug file.

        Writes the message and execption to the VersaLex debug file if the Debug Option, URI, is enabled and the System Debug Level is Debug or higher.

        Parameters:
        message - Message to write to the debug file.
        ex - Exception to be logged.

      • debug

        public static void debug(boolean always,
                         java.lang.String message,
                         java.lang.Throwable ex)
        Writes a message and exception to the VersaLex debug file.

        If always is true, then it writes the message and exception to the VersaLex debug file even if the Debug Option, URI, is not enabled. However, the System Debug Level must be Debug or higher in order for the message to be logged.

        Parameters:
